body:
All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13477/

Hi Cheng Hao,  Thanks for implementing these functions.  I bet they will be much faster than using HiveUDFs as we do now!

Based on the number of comments on the test case refactoring, I think it would be easiest to try and commit just the LIKE and RLIKE with a few simple test cases, and then take on the rest in a separate PR.

Thanks for the feedback, Tom.

Regarding "primary binary" and "jar", to clear up confusion I'm just going to call it "app jar" for now and if/when we add support for non-jar binaries we can find something more suitable.

Regarding arg vs. args, I found the plural in args confusing - it makes it seem like the parameter should take multiple values when in fact it takes a single value and can be specified multiple times.  Other parameters with plurals, like "jars", don't work this way.  We could possibly add --arg and deprecate --args for the spark-class way?

All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13481/

All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13480/

This bit me again, so I'm coming back to it.  I changed the check based on Matei's suggestion.  I also briefly investigated if there was more information in a `KryoException` that we could use instead. Sadly, it does not look like there is.  I guess they assume you will do your own bookkeeping about how many object to deserialize, so consider this a "real" error, not EOF.

Okay, I looked into this.  Part of it is #142 again... ugh. I bumped that PR so we can hopefully get it in and have more helpful error messages in the future.  The other problem is that Scala maps are not serializable as they don't have a no arg constructor.  To alleviate this I added a custom serializer in #243 that handles Maps as Arrays and then converts them back on the other side.  Not super efficient, but we are going to write out own serializer soon enough.

After those are in, I think this PR will pass tests and be good to go.

`LocalActor` has 4 threads to handle Actor messages but the replacement of the ContextClassLoader happens only one of them.
I believe that the **UNBALANCED** state is not desirable.

Your patch can fix my original problem but the undesirable state remains.

Hm - the `LocalActor` creates an `Executor` - the `Executor` creates a threadpool. When a task runs inside of the threadpool, the first thing it does is call:

```
Thread.currentThread.setContextClassLoader(replClassLoader)
```

So this replacement happens inside of the child threads also.
Or is there another set of threads you are referring to?
Ah I see - you mean the threads for the actor system itself.
I am merging this in, since this change doesnt affect any of the tests that Jenkins runs.
Yes, I mean the actor system's threads should be clean.

On 2014/3/27 1:25, Patrick Wendell wrote:

> Hey @scwf https://github.com/scwf I didn't realize - but this was
> fixed already in parallel by #201
> https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/201 (merged by @aarondav
> https://github.com/aarondav). Mind closing this?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/192#issuecomment-38713226.
> 
> ok, close it

I merged it in, but then realized that this was unnecessary. This PR was against scala-2.10 branch, which we dont use any more. In fact the sbt/sbt.cmd script does not exist in the Spark master any more, as we dropped support for building on Windows. And the scala version is correct on master spark-class2.cmd

Hey @haoyuan and @RongGu, thanks for the recent changes. I've looked at this and I have a few high-level questions:

1) Is there any way to have the unit test for this on by default? What's required to set it up? This is a pretty major piece of functionality and it would be good to test it by default.

2) What happens if someone creates a StorageLevel with useTachyon = true and replication > 1? Do we get two files? Do they step over each other?

3) Related to 2, in the first version we might want to let users put useTachyon only if useMemory and useDisk are false (and possibly the same with replication). That would reduce the number of weird interactions. I don't see when you'd want both Tachyon and disk for example, and furthermore Tachyon doesn't notify us when something falls out of it.

Ya okay I see. I'm wondering if there is some reason this needs to be set when running in non-local modes. It looks like this was added a really long time ago and stuck around through several refactorings:

https://github.com/apache/spark/commit/b864c36a#diff-40f975518e47d34cc8ecd7a49440228dR50

One thing we could do to be safe is something like this:

```
if (!isLocal) Thread.currentThread.setContextClassLoader(replClassLoader)
```

Or if we wanted to be more cavalier we could just remove it entirely.

I can't close it. You need to close it.
I'm not sure this covers all public methods everywhere... but it's a good start.
Thank you @marmbrus  for so detailed comments, I will separate them as 2 PRs.
Thanks I merged this. I cited @witgo as an author in the commit, since his original patch covered a lot of this.
Hey @witgo mind closing this? We fixed it #240 based on your patch.
Somehow this is no longer mergeable. Do you mind bring it up to date? Everything looks good.
I wonder if we should just get rid of FastUtil -- it's a big dependency (due to having lots of specialized classes) and we only use it in a few places.

Hey @marmbrus on this one would you mind creating a JIRA? And in particular if there is a symptom you encountered that would be helpful to know. I could see other people running into this and it might be helpful to track.

good call, will do.

Hey TD - I talked to @andrewor14 and he says he doesn't need it. So maybe we could remove `BoundedHashMap` and `WrappedJavaHashMap` as well? This extra factoring doesn't make as much sense now and will cut down on the complexity of the change a lot.

@pwendell , @srowen @markhamstra 
To maintain org.scala-lang: \* has the same version.The following configuration is necessary

``` xml
   <dependency>
      <groupId>org.scala-lang</groupId>
      <artifactId>scala-actors</artifactId>
      <version>${scala.version}</version>
      <scope>test</scope>
   </dependency> 
```
This was a false failure, I think jenkins timed out training to update github.
Usually when that happens, we just give up on the patch. The Jenkins oracle is all-knowing.
Add a lifecycle interface is a good idea?

BTW, one other change: instead of naming this new storage level TACHYON, I'd prefer to name it OFF_HEAP. The reason is that in the future we might want to support other off-heap storage modes as well, and we don't want users to rewrite their program, or developers to keep adding boolean flags in StorageLevel. This change will require updating the name of it in the code, as well as some of the docs.

One final thing about the config properties and docs:
- Make all the config properties start with the same prefix -- we now have `spark.tachyonmaster.*`, `spark.tachyonstore.*` and `spark.tachyonStore.*`. I think the best name is `spark.tachyonStore.*`. For the `spark.tachyonmaster.address`, maybe call that "master" or "URL".
- Document these properties in `docs/configuration.md`.
(Specifically the fastutil JAR is about 16 MB, which is about one sixth of our assembly JAR!)
Oh... Is that OK? That's strange...
